prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: To cover the CO(J=1-0) transition we will use a single 1.875 GHz baseband with 975 kHz spectral resolution (~3.3 km/s). We will apply significant spectral binning to this data in post-processing, in order to sample the line with approx. 30-50 km/s channels. The continuum spectral resolution (~104 km/s) would thus be too coarse for our purposes.

For the SLED analysis which will be anchored to the ground state CO transition we require only intermediate resolution in order to be able to achieve a stringent constraint on the excitation level of the CO transitions with J>4, separately for QSO & companion. We wish to separate the companion galaxy into two distinct regions, namely the northern (southern) sector which lie on (off) the jet axis, respectively. Given the intrinsic source size of the companion galaxy reported by Papadopoulos et al. (2008) - about 2.5" - this implies that we need ALMA configuration C36-3 with an angular resolution of 1.3" at the frequency of the redshifted CO(J=1-0) transition (89.60 GHz). The largest angular scale specified corresponds to the major axis of the deconvolved CO(J=1-0) source size reported by Papadopoulos et al. (2008) based on their ATCA observations.

Our aim is to achieve a robust (S/N=10) detection of the CO line flux in an individual resolution element when integrated over a 100 km/s channel (~30 MHz at the source redshift). This S/N level and frequency resolution is indispensible to ensure a good sampling of the line profile, even if the line width in an individual ALMA resolution elements should turn out to be smaller than the total FWZP line width of 570 km/s measured by Papadopoulos et al. (2008) for the spatially unresolved CO(J=1-0) emission from HE0450. We have inferred the expected strength of the resolved CO(J=1-0) flux based on unresolved CO(J=1-0) flux measured with the Australian Telescope Compact Array (ATCA) by Papadopoulos et al. (2008) who found it to stem from a source with intrinsic size 2.5"x1.5" (FWHM) after deconvolution. At the redshift of HE0450-2958 (z=0.286) the J=1-0 transition is redshifted to 89.60 GHz. The FWHM of our desired synthesized ALMA band 3 beam at this frequency is 1.3" (see box below), implying that the area of the source detected with ATCA is covered by 2.3 independent resolution elements with ALMA. For detection purposes, the most conservative scenario is to assume that the ATCA CO(J=1-0) flux of ~10 mJy is distributed homogeneously, leading to a CO(J=1-0) peak flux of S(CO)=4.4 mJy in an individual ALMA beam.

To cover the CO(J=3-2) transition we will use a single 1.875 GHz baseband with 975 kHz spectral resolution (~1 km/s). While the coarser spectral resolution offered by the continuum setup (~35 km/s) might suffice the velocity width of the CO-transition in the individual resolution elements within the companion galaxy are very hard to predict. We thus prefer the high spectral resolution option and will apply spectral binning as required to this data in post-processing.

For the companion galaxy we wish to chart spatial asymmetries and velocity anomalies generated by mechanical energy input from the jet. For this purpose we require ALMA configuration C36-3 which provides an angular resolution of 0.4 at the redshifted CO(J=3-2) frequency. This resolution not only gives us ~20 independent resolution elements across the galaxy, it is also well-matched to the size of the emission line blobs that define the jet axis. The largest angular scale specified corresponds to the major axis of the deconvolved CO(J=1-0) source size reported by Papadopoulos et al. (2008) based on their ATCA observations.

At the redshift of HE0450-2958 (z=0.286) the J=3-2 transition is redshifted to 268.80 GHz. We will image the CO(J=3-2) transition with a resolution of 0.4 (see box below). A resolution of 0.4 (see box below) will provide 20 independent resolution elements over the deconvolved ATCA source size determined by Papadopoulos et al. (2008). SMA follow-up of the CO(J=3-2) transition provided a 3-sigma upper limit of 20 mJy per 1.2x0.94SMA synthesized beam, corresponding to an upper limit on the excitation of the CO(J=3-2) transition r31=0.4. Our rms goal for this observation ensures a S/N=10 detection per resolution element and 100 km/s channel (~90 MHz at the source redshift) for a Milky-Way-like excitation (r31~0.25). Here we have again conservatively assumed a uniform flux distribution and extrapolated to the CO(J=3-2) flux based on the known CO(J=1-0) flux from ATCA. The peak J=3-2 flux expected for Milky-Way-excitation is S(CO)=1.1 mJy. A signal-to-noise of 10 is indispensable for studying the possibly perturbed gas dynamics of the QSO and companion galaxy due to the influence of the radio jet on their ISM: (a) we need to be able to locate the CO line peak with high confidence in each resolution element (where the line width may be significantly less than the galaxy-integrated FWZP velocity width of 570 km/s), and (b) spatial asymmetries may be most evident in the lower-intensity regions on the perimeter of the companion galaxy.

We will use four basebands with coarse continuum spectral resolution. The velocity resolution for the CO(J=4-3) transition will be 26 km/s which is sufficient to sample the velocity profile of the galaxy-integrated line emission.

For the SLED analysis we require only intermediate resolution in order to be able to achieve a stringent constraint on the excitation level of the CO transitions with J>4, separately for QSO & companion. We also wish to separate the companion galaxy into two distinct regions, namely the northern (southern) sector which lie on (off) the jet axis, respectively. Given the intrinsic source size of the companion galaxy reported by Papadopoulos et al. (2008) - about 2.5" - this implies that we need ALMA configuration C36-1 with an angular resolution of 1.1" at the frequency of the redshifted CO(J=4-3) transition (358.51 GHz). This resolution is also well suited for the band 7 continuum observations whose principal aim it is to determine ISM masses for the QSO and companion galaxy using the Rayleigh-Jeans tail and without being affected by source blending. The largest angular scale specified corresponds to the major axis of the deconvolved CO(J=1-0) source size reported by Papadopoulos et al. (2008) based on their ATCA observations.

The band 7 integration time is driven by the continuum sensitivity required to detect the 850 um sub-mm continuum with S/N~7. The expected continuum flux is 0.5 mJy; in estimating the integration time required for a S/N=7 detection we have subtracted the bandwidth that covers the CO(J=4-3) transition. This leads to an integration time of ~13 minutes. Assuming a Milky-Way-excitation (r41~0.17) of the CO(J=4-3) line we expect a S/N=17 detection in a 100 km/s channel and per resolution element. (The flux per resolution element has been estimated as for CO(J=1-0) and CO(J=3-2).) In combination with the CO(J=1-0) flux this should ensure a very good constraint on the amount of gas potentially shock-excited by the jet in the companion galaxy and the emission line blobs.
Our target can be observed for several hours during the night-time starting from late February 2016 (leaving approx. a month before the end of the required configuration C36-1). This high-frequency component of our proposal should thus be feasible barring unusually poor weather conditions for extending over several weeks.

We will use four basebands with coarse continuum spectral resolution. The velocity resolution for the CO(J=7-6) transition will be 15 km/s which is sufficient to sample the velocity profile of the galaxy-integrated line emission.

For the SLED analysis we require only intermediate resolution in order to be able to achieve a stringent constraint on the excitation level of the CO transitions with J>4, separately for QSO & companion. We also wish to separate the companion galaxy into two distinct regions, namely the northern (southern) sector which lie on (off) the jet axis, respectively. Given the intrinsic source size of the companion galaxy reported by Papadopoulos et al. (2008) - about 2.5" - this implies that we need ALMA configuration C36-1 with an angular resolution of 0.6" at the frequency of the redshifted CO(J=7-6) transition (627.20 GHz). This resolution is also well suited for the band 9 continuum observations whose principal aim it is to determine ISM masses for the QSO and companion galaxy using the Rayleigh-Jeans tail and without being affected by source blending. The largest angular scale specified corresponds to the major axis of the deconvolved CO(J=1-0) source size reported by Papadopoulos et al. (2008) based on their ATCA observations.

The band 9 integration time is driven by the continuum sensitivity required to detect the 450 um sub-mm continuum with S/N~7. The expected continuum flux is 4.4 mJy; in estimating the integration time required for a S/N=7 detection we have subtracted the bandwidth that covers the CO(J=7-6) transition. This leads to an integration time of ~15 minutes. With this integration time we will have sufficient sensitivity on the CO(J=7-6) line to robustly detect a any significant high-excitation component (r71>0.2) should it be present.
Our target can be observed for several hours during the night-time starting from late February 2016 (leaving approx. a month before the end of the required configuration C36-1). This high-frequency component of our proposal should thus be feasible barring unusually poor weather conditions for extending over several weeks.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: HE0450-2958 is one of the best low-redshift candidates for observing jet-induced star formation in the vicinity of QSOs. Previous multi-wavelength studies have provided suggestive but not uncontestable evidence for a jet in the HE0450 system. We now have new, high-resolution JVLA-imaging revealing (a) jet-like outflows from the QSO aligned with the nearby starburst galaxy and blob of ionized gas, and (b) a ~20 kpc diffuse halo of synchrotron emission enveloping QSO & starburst companion, possibly due to 'jet wobbling'. These new findings make it imperative to perform a comprehensive study of the effect (e.g. both positive and negative feedback) of the energetic outflows on the gas and dust in/around HE0450. Long wavelength observations (total time: 5.4 h) with ALMA of the sub-mm continuum and multiple CO-lines with high-angular resolution will give us the necessary information to (1) map the distribution of gas and dust in and between the QSO and companion galaxy, (2) confirm/exclude the presence of molecular outflows from the QSO, and (3) search for shock-excited gas in the starbursting companion, with the aim of solidifying/refuting the hypothesis of jet-induced star formation.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Department of Physics & Astronomy, Sussex, University of
